faq.question: React Native or Flutter?
faq.answer: If you already have a React web app — choose React Native, your team can reuse knowledge. Flutter offers better performance and full UI control. For most business apps the difference is minimal.

faq.question: When is native development needed?
faq.answer: For maximum performance (games, AR/VR), specific device APIs (HealthKit, ARKit), or when Apple/Google require native code. In the remaining 90% of cases cross-platform is the optimal choice.

faq.question: How long does publishing take?
faq.answer: Google Play — 1-3 days for first release. App Store — 1-7 days, first release can take up to 2 weeks. We prepare all materials in advance and know store requirements.

faq.question: How to update app without release?
faq.answer: We use CodePush for React Native and Shorebird for Flutter. You can update JS code and UI without store publishing. Native code still requires release.

faq.question: Which model to choose: GPT-4, Claude or open-source?
faq.answer: GPT-4 — best choice for complex tasks and multilingual communication. Claude — excellent for long document analysis. Open-source (LLaMA, Mistral) — when data privacy matters or fine-tuning is needed. We often use combinations: open-source for simple tasks, GPT-4 for complex ones.

faq.question: How to ensure data security when using AI?
faq.answer: Multiple protection layers: using APIs with privacy guarantees (data not used for training), deploying open-source models on your infrastructure, data anonymization before sending, encryption in transit and at rest.

faq.question: How much data is needed for AI training?
faq.answer: For RAG (document search) — your existing documents are enough. For fine-tuning you need 100-1000 quality labeled examples. For training from scratch — millions of examples. In 90% of cases RAG + prompt engineering is sufficient.

faq.question: Will AI hallucinate and give wrong answers?
faq.answer: Risk exists, but we minimize it: RAG ties answers to your documents, we tune model temperature, add fact checks, show sources. For critical scenarios we add human in the loop.

faq.question: What's the difference between audit and pentest?
faq.answer: Audit is a comprehensive check of all security aspects: processes, policies, configurations, code. Pentest is simulating a real attack to find and exploit vulnerabilities. We usually recommend starting with an audit, then conducting regular pentests.

faq.question: How often should security checks be done?
faq.answer: Full audit — once a year or after major changes. Pentest — at least annually, preferably every 6 months. Automated scanning — weekly. For critical systems, we recommend a Bug Bounty program.

faq.question: Won't the pentest break our production?
faq.answer: We agree on scope and testing methods in advance. Destructive tests are only done in staging. For production, we use safe methods. We always have a rollback plan and work during agreed windows.

faq.question: What if you find a critical vulnerability?
faq.answer: Critical vulnerabilities are reported immediately (within an hour), not waiting for the final report. We provide temporary mitigation recommendations. We help with emergency fixes if needed.
